channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: 3 Who Stopped Train Attack Were Boyhood Friends
item.description: The three Americans who subdued a gunman aboard a train to Paris are friends from their middle-school days, and two of them serve in the armed forces.
item.dc:creator: ASHLEY SOUTHALL
item.media:description: Alek Skarlatos, left, a specialist in the Oregon Army National Guard, and Mr. Stone.

item.title: Migrants Rush Across Border in Macedonia
item.description: Thousands of refugees managed to get past a cordon set up to prevent them from crossing into the country from Greece.
item.dc:creator: ALEKSANDAR DIMISHKOVSKI

item.title: A Shot, a Glimpse of an AK-47, and U.S. Servicemen Pounced on Gunman on Train
item.description: The quick action by two servicemen on a high-speed train traveling from Amsterdam to Paris averted what officials said could have been a blood bath.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: Airman First Class Spencer Stone left the hospital on Saturday in Lesquin, France, after being treated for injuries sustained while subduing a gunman.

item.title: 7 Dead as Fighter Jet Crashes Into Highway at British Airshow
item.description: A fighter jet taking part in a British airshow in West Sussex, on England’s southern coast, crashed into a busy road.
item.dc:creator: DANNY HAKIM

item.title: A British House Overflowing With Lords Draws Scorn
item.description: Amid European disenchantment with political institutions, criticism of the ever-expanding legislative chamber, the largest outside China, is mounting.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: The House of Lords in London. Both the chamber’s size, at 781 members, and its behavior have brought it scorn.

item.title: Kabul Suicide Bombing Kills 12, Including 3 Americans
item.description: A suicide car bomber targeted the vehicle of the Americans, employees of the military contractor DynCorp International, according to Afghan and American accounts.
item.dc:creator: AHMAD SHAKIB and ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: The site of an explosion in the center of Kabul on Saturday, where 12 people were killed by a suicide car bomber.

item.title: Profile Emerges of Suspect in Attack on Train to Paris
item.description: The gunman is believed to be Ayoub El Kahzani, of Moroccan origin, who was known to the Spanish and French security services and is reported to have traveled to Syria last year.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:credit: Christina Catherine Coons/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The police detained a suspect at a train station in the French city of Arras on Friday.

item.title: After 70 Years of Men, Some Say It Is ‘High Time’ a Woman Led the U.N.
item.description: Growing calls for a woman to lead the United Nations reflect not only an appeal for gender equity but also frustration with the opaque way in which world powers bargain over the appointment.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: Irina Bokova of Bulgaria, the director general of Unesco, has been brought up as a potential nominee for secretary general.

item.title: Fading Economy and Graft Crackdown Rattle China’s Leaders
item.description: A slowdown could mark the end of fast growth, while a campaign against official corruption has continued longer and reached higher than most had expected.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE and JONATHAN ANSFIELD
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China with President Obama in Beijing last year. Mr. Jinping will be visiting Washington in a few weeks.

item.title: 2 American Service Members Foil Gunman in Train Attack
item.description: The two men averted carnage by tackling an armed, suspected terrorist on a high-speed train traveling from Amsterdam to France, officials said.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: Several passengers were wounded Friday when a man opened fire aboard a train from Amsterdam to Paris. One arrest was made.

item.title: South and North Korea Hold Talks to Defuse Border Tensions
item.description: Officials from both Koreas met Saturday in hopes of heading off an escalation after an exchange of fire, South Korean officials said.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: South Korean soldiers adjusting barricades Saturday on a bridge near the border village of Panmunjom, where officials from both Koreas were expected to meet.

item.title: After a Promise to Keep in Touch, Obama and Modi Get a Hotline
item.description: The direct line of communication, a sign of the growing closeness of the United States and India, just recently became operational, White House officials said.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY MARCUS
item.media:description: President Obama and Prime Minister Narendra Modi agreed during the president's visit to India in January to establish a hotline between Washington and New Delhi.

item.title: Readers Address the Escalating Violence in Cairo
item.description: The Times asked readers how violence in Cairo has affected their lives as nearly two years of bombings have gradually changed the feel of the city.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Gay and Marked for Death
item.description: It’s time for enlightened countries to address a human-rights chasm.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: FRANK BRUNI

item.title: Open Source: For @UKLabour, RT = Endorsement, Apparently
item.description: Many supporters of the Labour Party were shocked to find themselves accused of being saboteurs.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: News Analysis: Prospect of Self-Inspections by Iran Feeds Opposition to Nuclear Deal
item.description: A military base in Iran has become a symbol of whether international inspectors are interested in digging into the past, or will just be checking boxes.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Investigation Lifts a Cloud Over President of Mexico
item.description: A seven-month conflict-of-interest investigation into the purchase of luxury homes by President Enrique Peña Nieto’s wife and his finance minister from a government contractor found no wrongdoing, Mexico’s comptroller said Friday.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Svetlana Boym, Scholar of Myth and Memory, Dies at 56
item.description: Ms. Boym, a Harvard professor who emigrated from the Soviet Union in her 20s, wrote of two types of nostalgia, one that clings to the past and another that realizes it is gone.
item.dc:creator: MARGALIT FOX

item.title: Airstrike Kills a Deputy to ISIS Leader, U.S. Says
item.description: The White House said Fadel al-Hayali was second in command to the militant group’s leader, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER and RUKMINI CALLIMACHI

item.title: Macedonian Police Clash With Migrants on Border With Greece
item.description: A day after the country declared a temporary state of emergency at border areas, officers used stun grenades and tear gas near the southern frontier.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: ALEKSANDAR DIMISHKOVSKI
item.media:description: Macedonian police officers clashed with thousands of migrants attempting to enter the country from Greece on Friday.
